Unit.Name: Whole body
Unit.Description: Use whole body when the results apply to the whole body.

Unit.Name: Blood
Unit.Description: The complete blood from a standard blood donation.

Unit.Name: Blood serum
Unit.Description: The portion of blood plasma that excludes clotting factors.

Unit.Name: Blood plasma
Unit.Description: The liquid component of blood, in which erythrocytes are suspended.

Unit.Name: Cord blood
Unit.Description: Blood that remains in the placenta and in the attached umbilical cord after childbirth.

Unit.Name: Cord blood serum
Unit.Description: The portion of cord blood plasma that excludes clotting factors.

Unit.Name: Cord blood plasma
Unit.Description: The liquid component of cord blood, in which erythrocytes are suspended.

Unit.Name: Venous blood
Unit.Description: The deoxygenated blood which travels from the peripheral blood vessels.

Unit.Name: Arterial blood
Unit.Description: The oxygenated blood in the circulatory system found in the pulmonary vein.

Unit.Name: Brain blood
Unit.Description: The blood present in the brain.

Unit.Name: Urine
Unit.Description: A non-invasive matrix definition for urine.

Unit.Name: Excreta
Unit.Description: Human waste (i.e., both urine and feces).

Unit.Name: Saliva
Unit.Description: The extracellular fluid produced and secreted by salivary glands in the mouth.

Unit.Name: Semen
Unit.Description: The fluid that is emitted from the male reproductive tract and that contains sperm cells.

Unit.Name: Breath
Unit.Description: The condensate of exhaled breath.

Unit.Name: Red blood cells
Unit.Description: The red blood cells.

Unit.Name: Breast milk
Unit.Description: The human milk as a biological system.

Unit.Name: Fat (adipose) tissue
Unit.Description: Adipose tissue, body fat, or simply fat is the main reservoir of fat in the body beneath the skin.

Unit.Name: Hair
Unit.Description: The human hair as a non-invasive matrix for biomarkers of exposure.

Unit.Name: Toenails
Unit.Description: The layer of cells situated at the base of the fingernail or the toenail.

Unit.Name: Big toenails
Unit.Description: The layer of cells situated at the base of the big fingernail or the big toenail.

Unit.Name: Outer skin
Unit.Description: The extracellular connective tissue matrix of the skin.

Unit.Name: Amniotic fluid
Unit.Description: The amniotic fluid is the protective liquid contained by the amniotic sac, serves as a cushion for the growing fetus.

Unit.Name: Placenta tissue
Unit.Description: The tissues which support fetal development.

Unit.Name: Uterus tissue
Unit.Description: The uterus or womb is the organ in the reproductive system that accommodates the fetal development until birth.

Unit.Name: Uterus
Unit.Description: The uterus or womb (organ) as biological matrix.

Unit.Name: Liver
Unit.Description: The liver as biological matrix.

Unit.Name: Muscle tissue
Unit.Description: Perfused (muscle) tissue.

Unit.Name: Viscera tissue
Unit.Description: Perfused tissue of the viscera, the soft internal organs of the body, especially the intestines.

Unit.Name: Exposed viable skin
Unit.Description: The viable skin, exposed to open air.

Unit.Name: Unexposed viable skin
Unit.Description: The viable skin, not exposed to the open air.

Unit.Name: Exposed stratum corneum
Unit.Description: The outermost layer of the epidermis, exposed to the open air.

Unit.Name: Unexposed stratum corneum
Unit.Description: The outermost layer of the epidermis, not exposed to the open air.

Unit.Name: Kidney
Unit.Description: The kidney organ as biological matix.

Unit.Name: Heart
Unit.Description: The heart as biological matix.

Unit.Name: Lung
Unit.Description: The lung as biological matix.

Unit.Name: Brain tissue
Unit.Description: Brain tissue.

Unit.Name: Brain
Unit.Description: The brain (organ) as biological matix.

Unit.Name: Gonad tissue
Unit.Description: The biological matrix of the reproductive system that produces and releases eggs (ovary) or sperm (testicle/testis).

Unit.Name: Slowly perfused tissue
Unit.Description: The biological matrix of poorly perfused tissue include skin and subcutaneous tissue, and resting muscle.

Unit.Name: Richly perfused tissue
Unit.Description: The biological matrix of richly perfused tissue include liver, heart, lungs, kidneys, and brain.
